title: ‘Get off our land’ plea after trespassers cause anguish
story: FARMERS in the Saul area outside Downpatrick have issued an impassioned plea to trespassers mdash get off our land.The farmers say they have been bedevilled by trespassers for years and are now totally fed up.In the latest incident a gate was left open and cattle were able to get into a nearby barley field, causing substantial damage to the valuable crop.In other incidents fields have been strewn with rubbish, while dog faeces, which is potentially harmful to cattle, has been found in a field used for making silage.The farmers have enlisted the support of South Down MLA Colin McGrath, who has issued an appeal for respect of local farmland and for walkers to refrain from trespassing.One farmer is considering installing expensive CCTV equipment in an attempt to identy trespassers.The farmer said that after years of many incidents the most recent event was the ldquostraw that broke the camelrsquos back.ldquoSomeone rang me to say the they had seen the cattle running and a walker had been seen over the land, the farmer remarked.ldquoThis person must have left the gate open to the neighbouring field because at .pm that night I got a call to say that the cattle were running over the barley field.ldquoTwo hours later we got the cattle out, but the barley had just been sprayed with a fungicide, so I am hoping that there is no long term damage done to the cattlethey had digested it. There was substantial damage done to the crop.The farmer continued: ldquoI also had a man who was purposely letting his dog into a field to go to the toilet every morning. This field is used to cut silage for the animals to eat in winter. What these people donrsquot understand is that dog faeces is potentially harmful to cattle.ldquoI appreciate that people like to go for a walk and it is unprecedented times where people are more cautious about meeting people on the roads, but they canrsquot use farmland as recreational ground.ldquoThat is a farmerrsquos work space and every blade of grass is used in farming, eventhere areno cows in the field that they are walking in. The ground is being used for something, be it winter fodder or rotational grazing.ldquoThere are cows calving in my fields and what I am more worried about is that someone is going to get hurt. Cows are extremely volatile around calving season and they will attackthey think their young are in danger.ldquoThe most dangerous animal on a farm is not a bull, itrsquos a newly calved cow. They can and will kill. People think that cows are docile but they can kill.The farmer added: ldquoI am having to look into getting professional CCTV equipment put in place over the land, an expense I could really do without.Mr McGrath said people walking through gated fields, leaving the gates lying open and allowing the livestock to get out placed an ldquounnecessary burden on farmers.ldquoWith some Covid- restrictions being eased itrsquos great to see that people are able to get out and about a bit more whether that be for walking their dogs, going for a longer walk or run or just getting out and about. We need to make full use of our wonderful natural surroundings for our own health and for our own emotional and psychological wellbeing.ldquoHowever, there are issues creeping in regarding walkers and runners using gated fields and pieces of farmland as access points whether for a shortcut or just because they feel they can do this.He continued: ldquoWhen I was growing up in Downpatrick you didnrsquot dare trespass on the land. There was enough respect for the farmer and the great contribution they make to our local communities and as a child probably a healthy level of fear as well.ldquoI want our communities to respect our farmers and to appreciate that they give to the community so much more than they get back.ldquoSoyoursquore out and about and enjoying your walks or runs, please stick to the public roads and public rights of way..prettyPhoto

title: A walk in the pairc
story: LOCAL GAA clubs are gearing up for ato action.After a three-month lockdown caused by the Covid- pandemic, clubs can look forward to a resumption of gaelic games.Thatrsquos good news for players and spectators, who have been starved of action.The clubs were able to unlock their gates for the first time this week.From Monday they were allowed to open their grounds for small groups of people to use walkways.Non-contact training for club teams will begin on June , initially in groups of no more than ten players with two coaches.Full-contact training can take place from July , with underage games commencing on the same date. Adult club games can begin on July .Inter-county competition is scheduled to start on October  with training likely to begin in September. That means the likelihood of All-Ireland championships running into .The schedule is set out on the GAArsquos Safe Return to Gaelic Games road map which was announced last Friday.Down GAA has yet to announce its plans for the coming months, but it seems likely that there will be a curtailed programme in the county.County officials have been meeting to formulate arrangements, which will have be sanctioned by the Down County Board, after which clubs will be informed.It is not knownthe all county leagues will be played. However, it seems likely that championships will take place.A Down GAA spokesman said: ldquoWe will have a window of opportunity to play club championships and the CCC have been engaged in preparing for any possibleto play.ldquoAto play will bring with it a dferent set of challenges to what we have ever been used to and in the public interest we must embrace the challenges and regulations set before us to ensure the health and well-being of our members, their families and their friends.ldquoIt will be dferent, but by adhering to what we need to do we will have the opportunity to play games in the summer and autumn of .The spokesman said clubs were not permitted to train on council facilities or farmersrsquo land.The spokesman added: ldquoIn the interim we again remind our clubs to adhere to the regulations at present until the agreed dates as outlined.The spokesman had this message for clubs and players: ldquoBe patient and follow theto play protocol..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch homes plan gets green light
story: PLANS for a major private housing development on the outskirts of Ballynahinch have secured formal planning approval.Members of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee last week formally signed off a proposal to build  homes at an  acre site on land between  and  Lisburn Road.Last weekrsquos meeting was the first Planning Committee session to take place since the local authority cancelled all its statutory meetings in response to the coronavirus.The development, which includes a range of detached, semi-detached and townhouses, is close to the Lime Trees, Edengrove and Kinedale housing developments.Planners have confirmed that the proposed site is within Ballynahinchrsquos development limits and while plans were initially lodged to build  homes, the figure was subsequently revised to .The Department for Infrastructure is content that the proposed housing scheme can be accommodated within the existing roads network, while Northern Ireland Water said there is available capacity within the existing sewerage system to cope with the planned new homes and that planning permission has been granted for a new sewage pumping station on adjacent land.A number of objections were lodged in opposition to the housing proposal in relation to traffic and access arrangements, claims that the application had not been properly advertised and insufficient neighbourhood notication.However, planners were content that the scheme could proceed with their recommendation endorsed by local politicians.Planners say the proposed development is ldquoappropriate to the character and topography of the site and that ldquoadequate provision is made for public and private open space and landscaped areas as an integral part of the development.They also said that the new development would not have an ldquounacceptable, adverse effect on existing or proposed properties in terms of overlooking, loss of light, overshadowing, noise or other disturbance..prettyPhoto

title: Beleaguered tourism sector needs boost
story: RADICAL steps need to be taken to boost Northern Irelandrsquos beleaguered tourism and hospitality businesses in order to aid their recovery from the Covid- pandemic, according to Baroness Margaret Ritchie.Speaking in the House of Lords last week, she said the abolition of air passenger duty and a reduction in VAT would help preserve jobs and provide a much-needed economic boost.Spending on tourism in Northern Ireland amounted to a massive pound billion last year. The industry directly employs , people, with thousands more supported in work through the supply chain.The impact of the virus on the sector could be devastating, Baroness Ritchie told peers during a debate on measures needed to repair the UK economy.ldquoProjections indicate that this level of employment could be reduced by  per cent, she said. ldquoThere has been no spend in the tourism industry since March  and it will be late July before tourism outlets open.ldquoMany of those people who will find themselves out of work will have to rely on the benefit system which is already under extreme pressure. It is punitive and needs to be overhauled with the needs of people put at the centre of the debate.She continued: ldquoTo encourage visitors to come to our region to spend money and to invest in our economy, we need to protect our people.ldquoThat means we must ensure our shops are allowed to open subject to social distancing rules and the British Government needs to abolish air passenger duty and reduce VAT on tourism.ldquoThat would assist our hospitality industry and those employed in it as well as the many people who depend on it for their basic source of income. These fiscal measures could indirectly make contributions to reducing inequalities in our society and community. Baroness Ritchie said the furloughing of many staff within the hospitality sector was currently concealing the true extent of the job losses that would follow when the scheme was ended.She also said the pandemic had revealed the ldquodeep levels of poverty and inequalities that are entrenched within many communities.She went on: ldquoThere have been greater levels of dependence on food banks for essential food provisions. Many people are now out of work through furloughing ndash some of them might not there are redundancies as a result of a deep recession.ldquoMany businesses will find it dficult to survive. This impacts on our society and economy and can cause isions within our society to deepen. There will be a greater reliance on benefits.She added: ldquoNew economic and social affairs strategies need to emerge following the pandemic, and they must demonstrate that efforts are being made to address those inequalities.ldquoOpportunities need to be taken to reframe the welfare debate and ensure that the cap on benefits is removed..prettyPhoto

title: Call for restoration of full services at Downe
story: THERE have been calls for the reinstatement of services at the Downe Hospital.Baroness Margaret Ritchie and Alliance councillor Patrick Brown are both demanding the full restoration of services which were removed at the height of the Covid- pandemic.Baroness Ritchie says she has pressed health chiefs on the issue, but to date has not been given a timeline by the South Eastern Trust.ldquoIt is important that the work on the reinstatement of services and staff continues and that the timeline for doing so is published so that the public is fully aware of all the circumstances, she said.ldquoUndoubtedly, all the staff in the Downe Hospital, including medical, nursing and ancillary, have worked with very dficult challenges over the last few months and they deserve our support, solidarity and congratulations.Baroness Ritchie said she had been told equipment will be ed to the Downe and that the Trust was progressing plans for the rebuilding of non-Covid health and social care services.She said she had pressed senior management on the provision of endoscopy services at the Downe and was informed that the service recommenced in the day procedure unit on June .She said  patients were examined during the first session and that the Trust currently had  patients on their lsquored flag escalation listrsquo for endoscopy services.She said priority was being given to those with higher risk of cancer at this stage. ldquoThese patients are getting access to urgent endoscopy usually within the three-week target, she remarked.She added: ldquoIn response to my query about the scoping work for additional services to be provided at the Downe Hospital, the Trust has informed me that planning for the provision of services to be delivered from the day procedure Unit at the Downe Hospital is part of the overall work the Trust is progressing in relation to the rebuilding of non-Covid  health and social services.ldquoIt is also anticipated that other day case surgical work will recommence shortly afterwards.Cllr Brown called on the Trust to reconsider its decision to engage with a private firm to offer endoscopy treatment at the Downe and to reinstate the AE department, as well as investing in what he said were ldquomuch-needed services for the local community.He claimed privatising healthcare put limits on those who could receive treatment.ldquoOur constituents should have access to high quality local services, he said.ldquoWhilst the dficult and unprecedented circumstances caused by the Covid- pandemic have undoubtedly added a strain on hospital resources, the decision to involve a private contractor for endoscopy treatments should be swtly reconsidered.ldquoInstead, efforts should be made to find a cohesive solution with current medical staff and relevant unions, in order to safeguard our local services.He continued: ldquoThe decision to close the AE Department in Downe Hospital was taken to reallocate resources and staff to other hospitals to help fight Covid-, especially at the peak of the virus.ldquoWhilst it is understandable that medical services needed to adapt as a response to the outbreak, Downe Hospital failed to have a sufficient offering in terms of emergency medical care prior to the pandemic, with an AE Department that only operated for  hours of the day.Cllr Brown said a global health crisis should not be used as an excuse to remove or rationalise health services.He remarked: ldquoDowne Hospital is a vital local employer and necessary for the health and wellbeing of residents across the District.ldquoLocal rural constituents should not have to worry that they wonrsquot have adequate access to healthcare, as services have been displaced to Belfast or Dundonald.ldquoThere is a clear need to invest in services, restoring those lost and making Downe Hospital a centre of excellence for a iety of treatments, mental and physical..prettyPhoto

title: Cyclists saddle up to raise £66k for Downpatrick charity
story: A GROUP of cyclists spent a week in the saddle to raise money for a local charity recently.Thirteen cyclists completed a week-long charity ride to raise funds for Mainstay DRP Day Care Centre in Downpatrick.The event was planned by a member of the Mainstay DRP committee and cyclists ranged from novices to experienced cyclists who usually ride once or twice a week.Some cyclists used mountain bikes, others rode racing bikes and one rider, who is self-isolating,completed his miles on a turbo trainer at home.Participants were aged from -plus to -plus and their aim was to complete a total of , miles in a week, riding as iniduals to adhere to the social distancing rules.The , mile mark was achieved by the end of day three, with everyone pushing themselves to the limit. Motivated by the cumulative mileage achieved so quickly, and despite the very windy, stormy conditions during the last few days, the riders went on to complete an amazing , miles.Donations raised over pound, for Mainstay DRP Day Care Centre at Cumulus Heights, Downpatrick.Mainstay DRP supports adults with learning disabilities and or autism through the provision of daycare opportunities, residential and respite care and supported housing.The money will be used to purchase a kiln and a poly-tunnel, with surplus funds used to further enhance day care resources.For more information or to make a donation go to see Mainstaydrp or justgiving mainstay..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick defy North Down and the weather to secure cup
story: ON September , , Downpatrick beat North Down by six wickets to win the Irish Senior Cup.The match was played at Downpatrickrsquos Strangford Road ground and continued the Northern domination of the competition.Cricket, though, wasnrsquot to the forefront of the Linehan family, which provided three members of the side.Paul Linehan, son of Hugh and nephew of Alfie, recalled: ldquo was a terribly wet summer. Crops lay flat in the fields from the constant pounding of the rain. As a family of farmers it was an extremely dficult time.ldquoIn between the deluges we managed to scramble our way to the first Irish Senior Cup final and emerged victorious mdash a rare moment of sunshine that year.For Paul, then a teenager still at school, the memories of  years ago are still vivid.ldquoIt was my first year in the st XI, playing alongside my father and Alfie. They were  and  years young at that time and still playing well.ldquoIn fact, the following year, in the same competition, I sat in amazement watching Alfie blast a ton against a Bangor with John Elder leading the attack, having opened the bowling for Ireland against Australia earlier that summer in front of , people at Downpatrick.ldquoAnyway, Alfie smashed nine huge sixes, all clearing the Strangford Road end. This was at a spritely age of .ldquoAll of a sudden I realised the legendary tales of Alfiersquos big hitting were true. Dad always said he hit the ball much further than anyone . That innings remains the most memorable I have seen from a Downpatrick player. saw the ICU as it was then bring in bowl-outs to decide washed-out contests, with all  players trying to hit the stumps in a shoot-out.In the first round Downpatrick faced Leinster and of the  players who aimed, only one was successful mdash the aforementioned Alfie.Downpatrick had reached the final after a famous win in the lionrsquos den of Donemana, with Brian Ferris and Jim Patterson smashing unbeaten fties in an emphatic victory.ldquoThere was a lot of publicity surrounding the Irish Senior Cup which at that time was sponsored by Schweppes, said Paul.ldquoIn the years that followed, just like the inter-pros played for the Guinness Cup, everyone simply called the competition lsquoThe Schweppesrsquo. In more recent times, the Ulster Cup was known as lsquoThe Clubturfrsquo.ldquoBefore the final, BBC TV sent a crew down to interview some of us, and ironically record us bowling at the stumps. It was still raining. It took us ages to hit the stumpshellipI got abuse at school.ldquoNeedless to say, the final was washed out without a bowl bowled and the miserable summer continued. It was desperately disappointing after a week of huge anticipation.The toss for the venue of the replay was conducted over the phone between the two captains, Ian Shields and Derek McCann.Downpatrick won and the replay was scheduled for midweek, Wednesday, September , and North Downrsquos Robin Haire recalls the conditions werenrsquot really fit for cricket.ldquoDownpatrick had actual puddles of water on parts of outfield, he recalled. ldquoMy abiding memory of that final was the spray of the water when you hit it along the ground.ldquoIt was totally unplayable, but the authorities wanted it played and out of the way. Nowadays umpires would have said try tomorrow.The decider itself proved to be a turgid, low-key affair, with little atmosphere and a contest which matched the gloomy conditions.ldquoIt just felt like a midweek league game, said Paul Linehan. ldquoPeople were at work, there was no crowd to speak of, it was cold and it wasnrsquot much of a game.ldquoNorth Down batted first, we bowled and fielded brilliantly, and they scraped to just . Karl Quinn and man of the match Philip Lennon each took three wickets, Jim Patterson got two, while Brian Hodges and Brian Ferris got one apiece.ldquoWe opened with Keith Malone and Derek McCann and I was due to come in three. I was a very nervous  year-old when I arrived at the wicket after they had put on . Keith was going well and I just needed to stay in.ldquoAnyway, desperate to get off the mark, I predicted Robin Haire was going to bowl me a long hop. I was right back on the stumps, ready to smash it, when he fired in a quicker ball which crashed into my ankles in front of middle. Out for a duck in the All-Ireland Cup final. I was beyond devastated as cricket was everything to me.ldquoWe eventually won by six wickets as our experienced side adopted a safety-first attitude, taking no risks. Derek McCann lted the famous trophy and Downpatrick were All-Ireland champions.There were to be no champagne celebrations for the teenager though.ldquoUnfortunately, I was too young to down a couple of beers, so it was straight back home after the final for Dad and I, two All-Ireland champions.Six years later, Downpatrick would secure the trophy for the second time in one of the most thrilling encounters ever, overcoming North by three runs.There was to be no personal glory though for Paul Linehan as he missed out on the chance of redemption.ldquoThe disappointment of making a duck remains as I was never to play in another All-Ireland final, having been injured for the  victory, he said.ldquoHowever, all these years later, my  medal is still very much a prized possession..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C June 10%2C 2000
story: TYRELLA mdash Tyrella beach has retained a prestigious European award which recognises the quality of the local tourist facility.The beach is one of eight in the province to receive the highly sought after Blue Flag Award, the highest possible recognition for cleanliness.Down Council chiefs are delighted Tyrella has once again been recognised for its quality, and the amount of effort they put into maintaining it, in the annual Tidy Britain Group awards.The awards were officially handed over on Monday along with the prestigious Blue Flag which will continue to fly high over Tyrella for the next  months.The beach was rigorously examined in an unannounced inspection by a  of European experts who focused their attention on cleanliness and the environmental management of Tyrella.Council official Leonard Lawson said everyone was delighted their efforts have again been recognised.ldquoThe award also recognises the councilrsquos effort to manage the beach, provide information points, educational material and detailed displays in the beach centre, he said.ldquoThe water quality is also critical to ensure Blue Flag status is retailed and the council aims to continue to work hard to maintain its high standards.NEWCASTLE mdash Armed robbers made off with over pound, in cash yesterday morning after a hold-up at a Newcastle bank.The three masked men burst into the Northern Bank in Main Street at .am and order everyone inside to co-operate. One produced a handgun and pointed it at staff members while the other two went behind the counter and lted money from the cash drawers.They made off in a black Ford Escort, which police found abandoned at the Royal County Down Golf Club just minutes after the robbery. It had been stolen from the public car park of the Newcastle Centre a before the hold-up.Nobody was injured in the incident but, according to a police spokesperson, employees and customers were left in a state of stock.ldquoThere was pandemonium and a lot of shouting and yelling,rsquorsquo he said. ldquoPolice were in the area at the time and managed to locate the getaway car within minutes of the robbery. When they got to the vehicle, the engine was still running but there was nobody in sight.Extensive searches were carried out and police are appealing for anyone with information about the movements of the iniduals involved and the cars used in the hold-up.KILLYLEAGH mdash Killyleagh residents who are battling to have the townrsquos former high school reopened, are to meet shortly with education chiefs.They believe the talks with chief executive of the South Eastern Education and Library Board, Mr Jackie Fitzsimons, mark another signicant step in their campaign to have the doors of the school reopened to students.Mr Fitzsimons has confirmed he is prepared to meet representatives from the Friends of Killyleagh High School with the meeting due to take place within the next few weeks.Senior politicians including Strangford MP John Taylor, Assembly members and local councillors are all backing the campaign and believe that with other schools in the secondary sector heavily over subscribed Killyleagh High must be reopened.Over , people have signed a petition calling for the school to be opened and the group behind the campaign says the results of a questionnaire it launched last year ldquoprove beyond doubt there are enough students to ensure the reopening is viable.rsquorsquoLocal community worker Billy Walker said the results of the recent questionnaire provided what he described as ldquooverwhelming evidence of the need for additional secondary school places in the area.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Detectives investigating a shooting incident in Ballynahinch last week have issued an appeal for information.They want to hear from anyone who was in the Langley Road estate on Tuesday night and saw anyone acting suspiciously.A local man who was shot had to be taken to the Downe Hospital in Downpatrick where he was treated for his injuries before being released. It is understood the shooting is linked to a family feud in the area.Superintendent Brendan McGuigan, the local police chief, confirmed yesterday that while a number of people had been arrested in connection with the incident, no one had been charged.STRANGFORD mdash A replacement vessel is expected to be in operation on the Strangford ferry route by late .The new ferry will replace the MV Portaferry at a cost of pound million, creating a more up to date and efficient service on the busy route.But, according to the Roads Service Divisional Manager, Mr Jim Price, fares are likely to increase with the introduction of the modernised service.ldquoThe Roads Service already spends pound, a year subsidising current fares and this is unlikely to go away,rsquorsquo he said.BALLYHORNAN mdash South Down MP Eddie McGrady has welcomed a commitment by the Housing Executive to rehabilitating a Ballyhornan housing complex.According to Mr McGrady, the dwellings at Ben Derg Park require external and internal improvements.The improvement scheme is scheduled to begin in , but the local politician has vowed to continue to lobby for an earlier start date.Among the improvements to be carried out by the Housing Executive are the upgrading of heating systems, the repair-refurbishment of kitchens and bathrooms and the improvement of space standards to both bungalows and houses.DRUMANESS mdash Roads Service officials have been warned to ensure the provision of a new footpath at a dangerous junction in Drumaness is top of their priority list.The warning has been issued by local councillor Anne McAleenan who has been waging a lone crusade to have a path provided at the junction of the Old Park Road and Crawfordstown Road.Despite promises by Roads Service officials that the work will be carried out, Mrs McAleenan says she is still waiting and her patience is beginning to run out.SAINTFIELD mdash Saintfield is bracing itself for a show-stopping spectacular millennium festival.The action kicks off this Friday and the nine-day extravaganza ends with one of the major events on the provincersquos agriculture calendar, Saintfield Show.Organisers aim to provide people with a spectacle they will not forget in a hurry and promise the many events will highlight everything that is good about the area.In addition to providing a fun-filled festival, the organisers also aim to raise lots of money for charity and with the final touches being put to all the events this week.Organisers say the emphasis throughout the cross-community festival is having fun and turning the spotlight on a town which is rapidly expanding at the start of the new millennium.SPA mdash Clues about the lestyle of Downrsquos first inhabitants have been uncovered near Spa in one of the most signicant archaeological finds in the country.The first ever Neolithic home to be uncovered in County Down has been found at Dunmore Mountain, giving an insight into the community that lived in this area up to , years ago.It was uncovered by a team of archaeologists working on the Aquarius Mourne Water Project, a major pipeline development between Newcastle and Belfast.Fragments of pottery and flint tools are among the find, which experts say offer the only clues about the lives of those who lived locally from ,BC to ,BC..prettyPhoto

title: Late Coulter strike sends Down into Ulster semis
story: After a number of years in the doldrums Downrsquos footballing fortunes took a dramatic upturn in  when they reached the All-Ireland final. The journey to Croke Park began against DonegalDonegal -Down -ULSTER SFC QUARTER-FINALBENNY Coulter popped up late in extra-time to send Down soaring through to the semi-finals of the Ulster SFC with a magical goal to break Donegalrsquos hearts in Ballybofey on Sunday.Coulter, the undoubted man of the match, struck gold when he got on the end of a sweeping move involving Danny Hughes and Martin Clarke to secure a clash with Tyrone.Both sides started tentatively and Down midfielder Kalum King was yellow carded after five minutes, but Donegalrsquos Dermot Molloy escaped punishment after he clashed with Damian Rafferty.Molloy opened the scoring in the eighth minute with a point from play before both Mark Poland and John Clarke registered wides for Down.Donegal then hit Down for six when Molloy took advantage of some poor defensive play and lashed the ball past a helpless Brendan McVeigh.Down were up against it, but their nerves were settled when Coulter and Clarke pointed to leave Donegal with a - to - lead after  minutes.Poland converted a free to leave a point in it, but Donegal must have thought Christmas had come early when they bagged a second goal when Molloyrsquos shot came off the upright and Conal Dunne was on hand to steer the ball into the net in the th minute.Martin Clarke answered Downrsquos call with a point and this was followed up by a similar score from Hughes as Down trailed - to - after  minutes.Coulter had a good effort well saved by Paul Durcan before Molloy extended Donegalrsquos lead with a long range free. With  minutes gone Poland pointed for Down, but the impressive Molloy negated this score with a point for Donegal.The half closed with Hughes pointing for Down in the second minute of stoppage time with just two points between the sides at the break.Donegal opened the scoring in the second half when Michael Murphy converted a free, but Poland replied for Down with another converted free.Adrian Hanlon, who had replaced Christy Toye, tagged on a point for Donegal to give his side a - to - lead with  minutes left, but Hughes reduced the arrears with a superb point for Down.Marty Clarke left a point in it with a lovely score and Coulter fired over the equalising point in the th minute after good foraging by Benny McArdle.David Walsh fisted Donegal back ahead, but Durcan saved Donegalrsquos bacon at the other end when he twice denied Dan Gordon, who was now operating at full forward.Coulter, who had moved out the field, then fired over the score of the game to bring the sides level with only two minutes remaining and Marty Clarke lofted Down ahead for the first time in the game with only seconds remaining.Donegal had Rory Kavanagh to thank for sending the game to extra time when he pointed with the last kick of the game to make it - to .Coulter scored the first point in extra time and this was followed up by a score from Hughes as Down started to dictate matters.The first period of added time ended with Down two points ahead, - to -.Mark McHugh reduced the arrears within seconds of the restart Colm McFadden brought the sides level at - to -.The game was there for the taking and Coulter was perfectly placed to accept Marty Clarkersquos pass before firing to the net in a dramatic late twist.Eoin Wade replied with an instant Donegal point, but Down held out for an epic victory.Down: B. McVeigh, B. McArdle, D. Rooney, D. Rafferty, K. McKernan, J.Colgan, C. Garvey, D. Gordon, K. King, D. Hughes , M. Poland , P. McComiskey, B. Coulter , J. Clarke , M. Clarke . Subs: C. Maginn for J. Clarke, P. Fitzpatrick for McComiskey, D. OrsquoHagan for McKernan, S. Kearney for Poland, C. Laverty forPoland, R. Murtagh for Garvey.Donegal: P. Durcan, F. McGlynn, N. McGee, K. Lacey, M. McHughfor Gallagher, C. McFaddenfor D. Molloy, E. Wadefor Maguire..prettyPhoto

title: Mr Joseph McMcIlmail
story: MR Joseph McIlmail, of Crew Road, Downpatrick, died peacefully at home on Tuesday, April , at the age of .Joe, as he was known to his family and many friends, was the fourth child of the late John Joe and Margaret McIlmail, from Bright. He was a loving brother to Margaret , Eileen , Jimmy, Mary and the late John.At the age of  he left school and started his apprenticeship as a carpenter joiner at Ballykinlar Camp for Sintons. After serving his time, he went to work in England in the early s, ing for a period when he met his we Sylvia, who he married in .The couple moved to Coventry where Joe continued to work for a few years. They ed to Downpatrick where Joe worked for several well-known local building firms, including Casements, Hugh J OrsquoBoyle and Taggarts, before he commenced his own building firm. Joe was a perfectionist with a great eye for detail and took pride in all the work he undertook.Joe had several hobbies. He loved photography and never went anywhere without a camera to capture the moment. He took the official photographs for several weddings, but ever the perfectionist he always worried how they would turn out until they were developed mdash unlike in todayrsquos digital age.Many of his interests were connected to the sea and the coast. He enjoyed fishing and always owned a small boat to go on short fishing trips. He also loved joining friends from Strangford and Kilclief on trips to the Isle of Man.Sailing was another great passion, being a crew member on trips to the Scottish and Irish coast before getting his own yacht on which he and his we were the only crew.Joe loved being in company and valued friendship. He liked meeting up with friends and family and hearing as well as telling a good story. He often couldnrsquot finish his stories from laughing too much at the memory of what he was going to tell and his laughter was infectious.He is survived by Sylvia, sons Joe, Paul and Mark, daughters Margaret and Anne, grandsons Austin, Malachy, Joseph, Eoin, Brian and Jack, granddaughters Natasha and Aimee, great grandsons Callum and John, great granddaughters Scarlett-Grace, Amelia-Rose, Lily and Eva, the wider family circle, friends and neighbours. May he rest in peace..prettyPhoto

title: Planners give approval for latest phase at housing site
story: PLANNERS have given the green light for the latest phase of building work at the former Downe Hospital site in Downpatrick to proceed.Contractors were forced to abandon construction in March due to the coronavirus pandemic, but are now back building much-needed homes on behalf of Clanmil Housing.An initial  homes are being built part as part of the major social housing project at the sprawling site where around  new homes could eventually be constructed at a huge area which borders four main roads.The redevelopment of the former hospital site includes a range of housing types including apartments, two and three storey homes and bungalows.The former hospital and canteen building behind it mdash which are both listed buildings mdashhave been incorporated into the development plan as apartment blocks, with the development proposals for these formally approved this week.Planners have given the green light for  apartments and two semi-detached homes with construction work involving the partial demolition of the former hospital infirmary and administration buildings which will be extended to accommodate the proposed new-build.The planned development includes provision for open space, landscaping access and parking.Planning permission has also been granted for  new dwellings, comprising  homes and four apartments, on a pocket of land south of Pound Lane and west of John Street.It is understood that as part of the development of the entire site, the main entrance into the former hospital complex off Pound Lane will remain, while a new entrance is also proposed on the Ardglass Road side.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran said the work at the former hospital site will be ldquoinstrumental in helping address the need for more social homes in the town.In addition, he said that the construction of the new homes can assist with the social and economic regeneration of this particular area.ldquoThe redevelopment jigsaw is taking shape and it is great see new houses springing up from the ground at part of the town that was an eyesore after the old hospital closed in . It is hard to believe that it has taken  years to get to the stage we are at now at, but the sight of new homes going up is welcome, he continued.ldquoWhile the regeneration of this part of Downpatrick is vital, so is the impact the new homes project will have on addressing a critical shortage of social housing. Many of those in need of a new home are in the urgent need category and the sooner tenants can start to move in, the better.Cllr Curran explained that those in the urgent need category are the priority as far as housing providers are concerned.He also hopes that given the progress that is being made at the former hospital site that families may be able to move in before December.The councillor said the new social housing project will benefit the wider community by providing construction jobs and boosting buildersrsquo suppliers and hopes that those on the waiting list for homes in the town will be offered the new properties.He added: ldquoThis eagerly-awaited scheme is ridding Downpatrick of a derelict site which will be transformed to deliver modern homes in an area of high demand.Local SDLP MLA Colin McGrath also welcomed the plannersrsquo approval.He said: ldquoThe housing development at the old Downe site has been a protracted and drawn out process.ldquoHaving been in regular contact with Clanmil to see what were the outstanding issues holding this development back to hear that council planners are to approve the next stage of the development at long last is very welcome news.ldquoI look forward to seeing how this scheme progresses and how quickly we can get people into these developments.Mr McGrath added: Irsquom grateful for the engagement with Clanmil and look forward to continuing this into the future..prettyPhoto

title: Pompey dream
story: BALLYNAHINCH teenage soccer player Eoin Teggart has been given a massive career boost.The hugely talented  year-old has been offered a third year scholarship by Portsmouth.The Northern Ireland youth International joined the League One clubrsquos academy from Cltonville in September  and has blossomed ever since.He made his debut for the academyrsquos first team against Norwich City in the Leasing Trophy as helped set up two goals as Portsmouth reached the final against Salford City at Wembley Stadium.Academy manager Mark Kelly was full of praise for the youngster: ldquoEoin has got plenty of pace and crossing ability mdash now he just needs to hone in on a few things.He is one of three players to be offered third year scholarships by Portsmouth.Kelly added: ldquoThey all deserve this opportunity, but have to get their heads down and be ready to go again.The ultimate aim is to catch the attention of Portsmouth manager Kenny Jackett and secure a place in his first team squad.Before his move to Cltonville Teggart was part of a highly successful Ballynahinch United youth team that went unbeaten for two seasons in the South Belfast Youth League before spending some time at Ridgeway Rovers and Glentoran.He was also part of the County Down side that reached the SuperCupNI Premier final in .On the local soccer front meanwhile, Billy Heal has been appointed as the new first team manager at Dundrum United.Heal was unveiled at the weekend by club chairman Jim McIlwrath and Chris Hogg, vice-chairman and club captain.He takes over from Andy Smyth who will continue with the club as a player and committee member.For over  years Heal has been involved with football within South Down, starting off with the Valley Youth.For the last three seasons he was first team manager at Ballyvea, who led to a double in the Newcastle League.He then took Ballyvea into the Mid Ulster League where they gained promotion at the first time of asking, finishing runners-up to Annalong, and reached the final of the Foster Cup, which has still has to be played because of the coronavirus lockdown.A spokesman for Dundrum United said Healrsquos appointment had the committeersquos overwhelming support and that it was first time a person from outside the club had been appointed as manager.The spokesman said the the club was aiming for a top three finish in the league and winning at least one cup.ldquoBillyrsquos aspirations with Dundrum United are to install a winning mentality and a hard working ethos within the club with fitnesses his driving force..prettyPhoto

title: Report to be published on future of Ardglass harbour
story: DETAILS of a new initiative aimed at revitalising Ardglass harbour are expected to be published before the end of the month.Stormont fisheries minister Edwin Poots is due to unveil the first stage of a report from the Fishing and Seafood Development programme whichwill include a timeline for work that needs to be done at Ardglass and the other Co Down ports of Kilkeel and Portavogie.Earlier this year, Mr Poots met with South Down MLA Colin McGrath and local councillor Dermot Curran to discuss the future of the village port.They highlighted the importance of the Ardglass fishing industry to the district and wider South Down economy and outlined planned improvement work at the harbour, including deepening it to facilitate larger herring and mackerel vessels.Mr McGrath and Cllr Curran emphasised the need for additional investment in the harbour and its infrastructure, insisting that the port receives its fair share of funding to help enhance the existing fleet.They said that the harbour was ldquostrategically important for the Co Down fleet, highlighting its crucial role in driving the South Down economy and its location as a central hub for processing fish landed in Ardglass.The politicians said additional investment is critical to allow Ardglass harbour to expand with appropriate slipways provided for larger vessels to dock safely.Several weeks after the meeting with Mr Poots it was revealed that ambitious plans to redevelop Ardglass harbour could cost in the region of poundm.The figure is contained in a detailed consultants report commissioned to undertake an in-depth feasibility study to look at potential developments for the harbour which is home to Northern Irelandrsquos third largest fishing fleet.The key issue the consultants focused on was deepening the harbour to facilitate larger vessels, with work also undertaken to look at improving harbour conditions, berthing pontoons for smaller vessels and increased berthing facilities.In addition, the study included a comprehensive review of possible harbour layouts, historic document research, topographic and bathymetric harbour surveys, quay wall inspection above and below the waterline and computer modelling.The consultants also liaised with the Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairswhich has been given a copy of the consultants report ahead of further discussions with its officials on the way forward.Ardglass has the only all-weather harbour between Howth and Bangor and has three primary areas including the so-called fish dock within the south pier.Last August, ious concept layouts produced by consultants were reviewed by members of the Ardglass Harbour Developments group which has been set up to oversee the regeneration of the port. The concepts were subsequently amended in November.The prime focus is on deepening the harbour and moving forward, a cost effective approach may be to zone dredge levels in particular areas.Cllr Curran, who is keen to hear what Mr Poots has to say in a few weeksrsquo time, said there were plans to deepen the outer harbour by nine metres and the area adjacent to Cochranersquos building at the inner harbour by two metres to facilitate crab vessels.He confirmed that consideration is also being given to creating a pontoon with finger berths adjacent to the quay wall in front of Cochranersquos with gangway access for crab vessels. No leisure craft would be permitted at this part of the harbour.ldquoNew investment in Ardglass harbour can help sustain existing jobs and create new employment opportunities, said Cllr Curran. ldquoThe port plays a ket part in the local economy and is at the heart of village le.ldquoArdglass lands some of the largest quantities of prawns in Ireland and deepening the harbour will mean that larger fishing vessels that currently dock where, will be able to access local facilities.Cllr Curran also fears that not deepening the harbour could potentially lead to an economic collapse for the Ardglass fishing industry.He added: ldquoI look forward to hear what the fisheries minister has to say towards the end of the month and hope that it will be positively good news for Ardglass..prettyPhoto

title: Roadworks causing delays in town centre
story: A DOWNPATRICK businesswoman has called on Phoenix Gas to complete pipe laying work in St Patrickrsquos Avenue by next Monday mdash as promised.The company is investing poundm investment across East Down and to date has laid over  miles of natural gas pipeline, with contractors also currently working in Newcastle.Phoenix officials have been working with the Department for Infrastructure to identy areas where pipe-laying could be brought forward to avoid further disruption to traders, visitors and residents, with work in Downpatrick starting several weeks ago.A mains pipeline has already been laid in a number of areas in the town, with contractors recently completing work in the Edward Street area. Contractors then moved to Pound Lane and are now in St Patrickrsquos Avenue.Eleanor Telford, who owns Telrsquos Confectionary with her husband Alan, said that she believed that the pipe-laying would start outside her shop imminently.ldquoI suppose the work has to be done sometime and perhaps itrsquos better done now when things are still quiet, but I hope the work is completed within the time we have been told, she said.Motorists have faced some delays in St Patrickrsquos Avenue which feeds into Market Street, the townrsquos main shopping area.Phoenix hopes that by expediting its multi-million pound investment programme now, it will avoid further disruption later in the year, while also providing consumers with additional access to fuel choice before the winter period.The company insists that the safety of its staff and communities is of paramount importance, with the current pipe-laying work scheduled following ldquorobust risk assessment and the implementation of additional operational procedures, in line with government guidance.Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran also appealed to Phoenix to complete the work as quickly as possible and for road users to remain patient during the work in the town centre which he said will result in inconvenience.He said it was always anticipated the work on such a major investment in towns and villages across the district would result in some degree of disruption and inconvenience.Cllr Curran said that the arrival of natural gas provides consumers with an added element of choice when it comes to their heating needs and said the investment in Downpatrick and right across the district opens up new opportunities to thousands of homeowners and the townrsquos business community.ldquoPipe-laying on such a large scale along congested streets and town centres results in disruption and while issues have arisen in the past, Phoenix has always done it best to minimise disruption, he said.ldquoBringing forward the work in Downpatrick, especially as schools across the town are closed as part of the coronavirus lockdown measures, makes sense. However, there will be concern about this project across the business community..prettyPhoto

title: Sam helping lift spirits with nursing home gigs
story: A KILLYLEAGH musician is lting the spirits of residents at a local nursing home mdash despite the Coronavirus lockdown and heart surgery.For over  years Sam Miskelly has been entertaining the residents of Fishbourne House at Spa, with his accordion.However, his weekly visits were put on hold after he underwent heart surgery several months ago and had stents fitted.He recovered only for the Covid- virus to spread around the globe, which meant he was no longer to go inside the home.Undaunted, the  year-old former lorry driver now sets up his accordion, amplier and microphone in the garden of the nursing home and residents are still able to enjoy his tuneful medleys.Sam is a regular performer at old tyme dances at a number of local venues and it was at one of them where he met Mr William Brown, owner of Fishbourne House.ldquoOne night he asked meI would play music for the residents. Thatrsquos how I came to play at the care home, he explained.ldquoI just love going there. The residents love to hear music that reminds them of the old days.Before his operation, he played in ious church and community halls, but he always ensured that Monday evenings were set aside for the residents of Fishbourne House.Sam likes to play a mixture of music, including country and gospel, as well as some Elvis Presley hits.He first picked up an accordion when he was  and has been playing it since.ldquoIrsquove never been able to read music. Instead I recall every note from memory and Irsquove built up quite a repertoire, he said.Around  Sam gave up driving lorries to concentrate on the music scene full time and he has gone on to acquire a faithful following.He performed regularly at afternoon tea dances and music evenings at Raa Orange Hall, Ballygowan Village Hall and Comber Unitarian Church Hall until the coronavirus pandemic took hold.Sam and his we, Avril, who have been married for  years, have two children, Stuartand Christine , and four grandsons, Jamieand Harryand two granddaughters, Katieand Aoe .It was only when Sam celebrated his th birthday last year that the couple realised their daughter, Christine, could be following in her dadrsquos musical footsteps.During the birthday celebrations Christine got up on stage and sang the Doris Day song, What Ever Will Be Will Be.ldquoThere wasnrsquot a dry eye in the hall that evening, Sam recalled. ldquoIt was the first time we both learned that the entertainment gene wasnrsquot dormant in the younger generation.Instead of birthday presents everyone who attended the party in Killinchy Presbyterian Church Hall gave donations to the Helping Hands charity, which is closely associated with the Royal Belfast for Sick Children. A total of pound, was raised.ldquoThe charity helped my grandson, Harry, recover when he was admitted to the hospital as an emergency and placed on a ventilator for seven days in . He was just four years old at the time, Samuel explained.ldquoWe were so grateful to the team and wanted to give something back, so we arranged the evening.To his wersquos delight, Sam is using the lockdown to some gardening work which had been put on hold for some time.Their garden has never looked so good and now Sam and Avril enjoy relaxing outside during the warm evenings.Sam added: ldquoWe both really miss not having family and friends over to show them how nice the garden finally looks. We especially miss not seeing our grandchildren. That has been the hardest part of all.To find out more about Sam log on to www.sammymiskelly biography-page..prettyPhoto

title: St Patrick Centre opening welcome boost for tourism
story: LOCAL politicians have welcomed the reopening of the St Patrick Centre in Downpatrick which is hoping to cash in on people staying at home for their summer holidays.The international attraction mdash dedicated to Irelandrsquos patron saint mdash closed to the public as part of the lockdown measures introduced to combat the deadly coronavirus.And as the centre prepares for the expected visitor boom over the summer months, local politicians are delighted that people will soon be flowing through its doors again.Prior to the pandemic, the centre was in the process of implementing new measures to grow its business following a strategic review by Newry, Mourne and Down Council which saw the centre as being pivotal role in supporting other local tourist attractions.As a result, a new five star group of local attractions has been formed led by the visitor centre which includes the Down County Museum, Down Cathedral, Downpatrick Railway Museum and Down Arts Centre.South Down MLA Emma Rogan and councillors Oonagh Hanlon and Robert Burgess are hoping that the St Patrick Centre can benefit from a surge in visitor demand.Ms Rogan, who met recently with centre director Dr Tim Campbell, says she has every confidence that he and his staff are stepping up to the challenges they face as we look towards a lsquonew normalrsquo.She said Newry, Mourne and Down Council must also work with and support the requirements of tourism businesses to help them compete ldquoin the new world we are entering into.Cllr Hanlon said while the impact of Covid- has presented challenges for the local tourism sector, a crisis can give birth to opportunity.She believes there is an opportunity to reshape the tourism industry in a way which will bring opportunities to local communities and business and that visitors will play a critical role in helping the local economy over the coming months.ldquoThe St Patrick Centre is an excellent base for the proposed five-star model which will promote the heritage and attractions our area has to offer, suggested Cllr Hanlon.ldquoWith social distancing now the new normal, smaller groups are likely to seek out authentic experiences that allow the visitor to connect with the landscape and local communities.Cllr Hanlon said that she believes that rural areas can offer an alternative to built up city areas for breaks.Cllr Burgess, who described the visitor centre as a district facility, believes that the centre can make the most of people deciding to holiday at home this summer.ldquoTourism is what we do best in this part of the world and while this particular industry has been decimated by coronavirus, it will slowly start to rebuild, he continued.ldquoWith huge influxes of international visitors not going to happen, the time is right for people across the island of Ireland to visit our district and stop off at the St Patrick Centre and the many other historic and ecclesiastical locations that we are fortunate to have.Cllr Burgess said the visitor centre can draw people into the area and direct them on to many other attractions across the district.ldquoThe visitor centre is a key hub for the district and does a tremendous job. Like the staff who run the facility, I hope that the facility will benefit from a signicant uptake in lsquostaycationsrsquo this summer, he said.Cllr Burgess is also encouraging people across the district who have not yet made their way to the St Patrick Centre to do so during any free time they may have over the summer..prettyPhoto

title: Virtual charity Rock Down concert
story: AN evening of the best of local rock and pop will be hosted on Friday as the Rock Down virtual concert kicks off.Organised by three friends from the Downpatrick and Strangford area ndash Sean Wallace, Harry Deegan, and Patrick Buchanan ndash the event showcasing the best of local talent will raise much-needed funds for mental health charity, Downpatrick PIPS.Donations for the gig have already reached more than pound, and more is likely to come in after the event.Nine acts will perform mostly acoustic sets live via Facebook stream from their own homes or venues ndash suitably socially distanced ndash from pm to pm.Opening up the concert will be Nicky Brown from Ballynahinch and finishing it off will be The Overknights.Other local acts include the Just Adam Band, Petty Youth, The Renegades, Eamon and Charlie Hanlon, Steafan Hanvey and Kevin Young who has just finished off his debut album. Eamon and Steafan supported Sinead OrsquoConnor on her recent UK and Ireland tour.Circus performer Sideshow Ramon will be entertaining viewers during the interval with a selection of fire-eating and sword-swallowing performances.Patrick he and his friends had always intended to organise a live event in support of PIPS this summer but decided to run it as a virtual event due to the lockdown.He explained: ldquoWe are all music lovers and have been to gigs all our lives. We know a lot of bands and performers so it was easy enough to contact them and they were generous enough to say yes.ldquoDownpatrick PIPS is a cause we are all passionate about. Mental health problems, suicide and depression is blighting our society and the local work that PIPS does is invaluable.ldquoSupporting good mental health is vitally important and we need a service where people can talk to people when they are feeling down or depressed. PIPS are there to provide that support.The trio held a very successful fundraiser for Downpatrick PIPS, known as PIPS at the Pot, a night of music at the Lobster Pot in Strangford two years ago where pound, was raised.An impromptu jam session at Mullanrsquos Bar in Downpatrick raised a further pound,.Downpatrick PIPSrsquo co-ordinator Brenda McAteer praised the men for continuing to support the charityrsquos work and said that apart from raising funds, this event will act as a way of getting some people to think about their mental health and to ask for help.ldquoWe have been overwhelmed by the support and the creativeness of people raising money for us during the lockdown, she said.ldquoWhile PIPS at the Pot was a fantastic fundraiser, the awareness of our work that came out of that was phenomenal. It really got people talking and our referrals took off.We had people who contacted us after seeing the video released afterwards or by simply talking about their mental health on the night or someone they had lost to suicide and had never opened up about it.:Brenda added: ldquoWith Fridayrsquos event being a virtual event, we are hoping that it will reach even more people.To view the concert, visit www.facebook groups rockdown and to donate go to www.gofundme f PIPS RockDown.prettyPhoto

title: relaxation restrictions announced
story: Deputy First Minister Michelle OrsquoNeill said: ldquoToday we have been able to continue the forward momentum in our phased recovery plan. The scientic and medical advice to the Executive at this time is that we are in a position to move forward on a number of further relaxations.ldquoWe understand the pressing need to tackle the issue of isolation, which is particularly dficult for those in single-person households. So, from this weekend, those people living alone will be able to join with one other household and have contact with them indoors. We are actively reviewing the wider situation on indoor meetings with family and friends and will provide an update on that next week.ldquoIrsquom pleased that we have also agreed today to open up the housing market and permit house moves. This is particularly good news for those who have been living in unsuitable accommodation and families in temporary accommodation who will now be able to move into social homes that are waiting for them.ldquoThe issue of childcare is crucial in our recovery journey and our decision to permit the opening of church facilities and community halls for day care is an important step in addressing this key issue.ldquoI believe that the relaxations we are announcing today are a balance between the welfare, social, and emotional needs of our people, as well progress towards opening up our economy.Health Minister Robin Swann said: ldquoThe Coronavirus emergency has been the biggest test of our whole society in many years. In dealing with the immediate threat to public health, we had no choice but to impose restrictions that were not only dficult to live with, but were in themselves damaging to our wider economic, societal and personal wellbeing.ldquoThe Executive committed to keeping these restrictions under review and agreed that we would not keep restrictions in place longer than we need to. Today, based on the scientic evidence and medical advice on the prevalence of infection and the course of the epidemic, we have agreed to make some signicant relaxations to the restrictions that remain in place.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. The Ulster Farmersrsquo Union also used the opportunity to discuss the implications for local farmers post Brexit.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. That is what happens when whole tiers of economic activity have to shut .Explanations are needed as to the wisdom of some uses of taxpayer or ratepayer funds in this crisis, such as NI councils topping up the UK’s very generous furlough scheme so that the income of council employees on the scheme was untouched. Transparency is all the more important when there are huge demands on the public purse and when government will be essential to the recovery and must be wisely spent.Now is an obvious time to improve infrastructure. It puts money in the economy, it employs people and it leaves society with a lasting asset. The road upgrades that Nichola Mallon says her infrastructure department will now advance across Northern Ireland are all needed. title: brexit might be seen lower priority
story: Alex Kane: Indference on NI’s place in the Union has been Westminster norm since Edward HeathUmbro apologises for UVF-style colours in Linfield kit and says it will not promote itNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionColumnistsBrexit might be seen as a lower priorityAs the coronavirus crisis continues to dominate everyone’s thoughts, you’d be forgiven to think that Brexit might be seen as a lower priority.By Adrian Doran is Chair of CBI Northern IrelandTuesday, th June , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th June , : pm""Adrian Doran is Chair of CBI Northern IrelandAs the coronavirus crisis continues to dominate everyone’s thoughts, you’d be forgiven to think that Brexit might be seen as a lower priority.In fact, in Northern Ireland and for businesses across the UK, the importance of getting a good deal and implementing the Northern Ireland Protocol has never been more pressing.The UK Government’s paper on the Northern Ireland Protocol last month provided a much welcome indication about the UK Government’s plans – but there are still many questions that need to be answered. The Protocol was the compromise that avoided a no deal exit, it is vital now that the EU and UK work together to protect the peace and prosperity of those who will be impacted by it - the businesses and consumers of Northern Ireland. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...The Protocol is only one part of the jigsaw, and companies will have their heads in their hands about the worrying lack of progress following the latest round of talks. Anxiety is mounting amongst the Northern Irish business community that, let’s face it, has little resilience to spare.As we’ve begun to take the first tentative steps into the recovery phase, every decimal point of economic growth has to be fought for.With limited growth plaguing Northern Ireland’s economy for years, long before this current crisis emerged, the task is more urgent than ever before. The bottom line is getting a good Brexit deal for our economy is essential.That’s why businesses across the UK expect negotiators on both sides to approach talks with a determination to deliver.Negotiation by videoconference is far from perfect, preventing the kind of side-line conversations that can help smooth dferences in formal talks. Even more limiting is adhering to rigid negotiating mandates. Unless the dynamic shts in this latest round of accelerated talks, it looks like both sides will stay trapped in a holding pattern, with no trade deal a real possibility at the end of the year, when the transition period is scheduled to end. For businesses, jobs and economic confidence in this most challenging of years, that would be a shocking outcome which must not come to pass.For many Northern Irish firms fighting to survive, the idea of preparing for a chaotic change in trading relations with Great Britain in seven months is beyond them. They aren’t remotely prepared. Stockpiles built to weather a Brexit storm are long depleted and supply chains are fragmented by an unprecedented global pandemic. Many NI businesses, especially smaller ones, have burned through cash reserves they would have otherwise used for rainy days. On top of this, the support from the Jobs Retention Scheme and rates relief will be coming to an end for many businesses.The net impact of no deal would be higher unemployment at a time when we will be fighting for every job. Signicant losses, particularly in our manufacturing, retail and hospitality sectors, would simply be devastating for local communities and our economy.For everyone’s sake, the Protocol taking effect in a clf-edge scenario is not the answer. What is more, Northern Ireland will not benefit from the proposed flexibilities on post-transition border controls on goods, announced last week by the UK government.So, what needs to happen now Political leaders across Europe have shown in recent months that what previously may have been thought of as impossible, is not. They need to use that determination and leadership to find a route through in the talks.This must continue, building upon the conversation yesterday between UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.The global pandemic could end up claiming many jobs in Northern Ireland, and possibly millions across these islands. The stakes are higher than ever before. Walking away with no deal would be a major block to recovery. It would worsen inequalities, damaging regional and national growth. Many businesses are not – and cannot – prepare for the impact of no deal on top of what is happening.The UK Government has repeatedly ruled out an extension to the transition period, which means firms therefore have no choice but to plan on that basis. But that means a deal is now the only acceptable option.A good deal with the EU with a sustainable agreement on the implementation of the Protocol is necessary for renewal. As businesses start to get up and dust themselves off, and as we sht from revive to recover, a recovery plan that reaches all parts of Northern Ireland is essential. However, despite the terms of the contract having been torn apart by the Audit Office and the Assembly’s public accounts committee in , the deal with BT was extended to run until at least  – and civil servants are now negotiating yet another extension beyond that date.Mr Donnelly accepted that BT had performed well in delivering the project but found that it was making exorbitants, while the department was also benefiting from inflated fees, something he said was “an indirect local tax”.Although officials had secured some improvement in terms when they renegotiated the deal, Mr Donnelly said that to this day “LPS customers nonetheless continue to pay too much for the services provided”. He said that “users of the LandWeb Registration Services are being overcharged as the Fees Order  is out of date with fees set too high”, yet the Department of Finance has shown no urgency in updating the fees.Mr Donnelly, who played an important role in bringing the RHI scandal to public attention, found that the way in which the BT contract was extended “is indicative of poor strategic planning by the department”.BT makes its money from the fees the public pay for accessing the Landweb system. title: new app provide specialist advice gps seconds
story: The Consultant Connect app has been fast-tracked for use in NHS Wales to help deal with the covid- outbreak and support primary care in the long term to offer better advice and guidance to patients.By accessing speedy advice the new app will help prevent unnecessary hospital admissions and referrals and ensure that those needing hospital treatment are managed accordingly.The core service, being rolled out across Wales, gives clinicians access to specialists in respiratory medicine, cardiology, diabetes, palliative care and acute medicine for covid.Health Boards can also add access to a range of local advice that is appropriate to their patientsrsquo needs.A GP or other clinician accesses the service either by dialling a phone number or using the Consultant Connect app.After choosing a speciality from a menu they are connected with a specialist in an average of  seconds.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am very pleased we are able to start rolling out the Consultant Connect in NHS Wales."This will help to support primary care to determine the right treatment for their patients.ldquoRight now it will save crucial time for health care professionals and reduce the amount of hospital visits needed by patients, at a time when our NHS is facing extra pressure.ldquoIn the long-term the use of this technology is an important part of our plan for the future of health and social care,"A Healthier Wales."Making the most of technology is vital to us building a modern health and social care service, in which care is delivered closer to home. article_url   content_id
